"Terrorized"? The idea that one animal could "terrorize" another is ludicrous. (People terrorize other people, animals don't care how their victims feel.) Where did this writer learn about dinosaurs? From Fred Flintstone?

replies.context:
It sounds to me like you are whining.
But the reptilian brain has the same sympathetic nervous system in the brain stem as you that causes the 'fight or flight' response, so an animal can indeed feel terrorized.

Whining? No. Thinking. According to the THE CONCISE OXFORD DICTIONARY OF CURRENT ENGLISH (8th edition, 1990) "terror" is defined as extreme fear ... (created by) the use of organized intimidation". Thus, the difference between 'fight-or-flight' fear and terror ‚Äì instead of only  brain stem activity, complex reasoning* has to present in both the perpetrator and the victim. (* Current "thinking" is that in humans the frontal and parietal lobes of the brain are involved with higher-order cognition. The brain and the processes that drive reasoning include the rostrolateral prefrontal cortex, the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, and the inferior parietal lobule, with the rostrolateral region more actively engaged in second-order relational reasoning. If dinosaur brains even had these areas, they would not have been developed to the degree necessary for one species to "terrorize" another.)

The fear comes from the autonomic nervous system. That our highly evolved mammalian neocortex can give it a name is beside the point.
And I'm a zoologist, so I didn't need your useless wikipedia version of "current thinking" on the brain.

replies.context: This dino wasn't bigger than T-Rex.  It was bigger than the the Tyrannosaurs that lived at its time....
And interesting difference of opinion.

Not a difference of opinion.  Its a fact, did you read the article?  This dino got to about 30' in length.  T. Rex got to about 40'.   Also, they are separated in time by ~30 MY.  The point they are making is that Tyrannosaurs at the time of this dino were much smaller, the one mentioned in the article was ~10', and were likely kept that way due to competition from the larger allosauroids of the time.  When they died out, tyrannosaurus got bigger.
